name: Robin Devillers
position 2: Intern at Donders Centre for Cognitive Neuroimaging
skills: ['MATLAB', 'Elan', 'Presentatievaardigheden', 'Duits', 'Presentaties', 'Nederlands', 'Vertalen', 'LaTeX', 'Klantcontact']
summary:
In September 2022, I started my internship at the Donders Centre for Cognitive Neuroimaging as part of the second year of my MSc Cognitive Neuroscience (Research). My thesis will be under the theme of 'Intention and Action',  led by prof. Ivan Toni, Arjen Stolk and Jana Basnakova. I'm excited to learn how to analyse eye-tracking and pupillometry information, as well as fMRI preprocessing and first and secondary analyses, all while using Matlab. Additionally, I will be assisting in running EEG experiments. 
On the side, I will be working at the Max Planck Institute for Psycholinguistics as part of the Language Development Department. My main tasks entail running experiments with children, coding data, all while in close interaction with the researchers. A minor part concerns writing lay summaries for the Baby and Child Research Centre. 
In my free time, I am working on a paper on the difficulties of children on interpreting while-clauses in Dutch by using eye-tracking. 

Graduated cum laude from University College Utrecht in July 2020, with an interdepartmental major with tracks in Linguistics and Psychology, with a minor in Cognitive Neuroscience. My thesis was titled 'Dyslexia: a Methodological Approach of the Evaluation of Treatments' in which the current practice for children with dyslexia was assessed in light of knowledge from the scientific literature.

summary:
As someone who has finished a Bachelor in both educational science, both a bachelor and Master degree in English Language and culture, and is currently finishing an Educational Master for the English language, I have a vested interest in both education and language.
I have been trained in multiple forms of research, included but not limited to: qualitative and quantitative research, applied research, conceptual research, empirical research, case study research, diagnostic research, literature research, and analytical research.
During both my Bachelor and Master in English Language and Culture, I have specialized myself in literature research, with a specific focus on the research of science fiction, fantasy, graphic novels, and horror. I am, however, well-versed in the research of the entire width of English literature.
During my Educational Master I have specialized myself in didactics, specifically online classroom didactics and student differentiation. Moreover, I have also specialized in education reform and the role of the student withing educational systems. Additionally, I have ample practical experiences in teaching multiple age groups, ranging from young children to adults. I have experience in teaching the English language in its broadest sense; Ranging from literature, to grammar, to academic writing.
During my Bachelor in Educational science, I have specialized in orthopedagogy and the treatment of children with developmental disabilities within the educational system as well as the attitudes of professional caretakers and the role of these attitudes in the treatment of children with developmental disabilities.
I work well in a team, and it is my goal to be a part of the progression of education, either nationally or globally.

Currently I am doing my PhD research in youth work and vocational education at the Catholic University Leuven as part of the SoLiDi European research project.

name: Ferid Yusub
position 1: I'm the head of the international human rights organization "Communities of Human Rights Defenders".
skills: ['Rule Of Law', 'Public Participation', 'Civil Society', 'Customer Service', 'Leadership']
summary:
The organization in support of human rights defenders and activists is a community of international human rights organizations.
Anyone who considers himself a human rights defender or activist can also join our organizations.
In 2017, an organization was established to support human rights defenders and activists - a community of international human rights organizations.
Сommunities of Human Rights Defenders is an international human rights organization. We are fighting for human rights around the world. We are campaigning for a world where human rights are enjoyed by all.
Our organization is called upon to monitor the implementation by all state bodies of the national legislation in the field of protecting the rights and freedoms of citizens.
Human rights defenders and activists face various types of threats, especially in countries where the rule of law in which it began not so long ago. In this regard, in 2015, a special UN resolution was adopted - on the need to protect human rights defenders.
​
The main mission of the "Communities of Human Rights Defenders" is to promote the observance of human rights, to strengthen and advance civil society, to render all possible and diverse assistance in the development of the human rights and social movement by implementing projects and programs aimed at developing public participation, social partnership and the responsibility of the authorities " .

The organization develops and implements the following programs: "Society against Corruption" - "Prevention of Corruption by Civil Society".

​
Organization CHRDs, at the moment, as a young human rights organization, sets itself a series of tasks:
 
1. Cooperation with others, both human rights and non-human rights organizations
​
2. To conduct and participate in various seminars on human rights and NGO activities

​3. The organization needs various assistance for successful development

​

name: Ellen-Petra Kester
summary:
Dr. Ellen-Petra Kester is an Associate Professor of Spanish linguistics at Utrecht University. After receiving her Ph.D. from Utrecht University, she was employed at the University of Amsterdam where she continued her work on the syntax of Germanic and Romance languages. More recently she has been conducting research on the syntactic properties of Papiamento, the Spanish-Portuguese based creole language spoken on Aruba, Bonaire and Curaçao. 

Over the years she developed a strong interest in the language situation of the former Netherlands Antilles, where Papiamento and English, the mother tongues spoken by the majorities of the populations of the Dutch Leeward and Windward Islands, are co-official with Dutch. Since 2010 she expanded her research to language use, language attitudes and language policy  in relation to the multiple identities of the populations of the Caribbean island that are part of the Kingdom of the Netherlands.  

In 2013 Ellen-Petra Kester carried out a government mandated research project on the island of St. Eustatius, together with prof. dr. Nicholas Faraclas (University of Puerto Rico) and drs. Eric Mijts (University of Aruba), which led to a change in the language of instruction  in the education system of the island. 
In 2016 she joined a project funded by the Uitvoeringsorganisatie van de Twinningfaciliteit Suriname - Nederland (UTSN), developing a course as well as a manual on cultural diversity and multilingualism for teacher trainers in Surinam. 

Ellen-Petra Kester has been the coordinator of a Master’s program on multilingualism and language acquisition (Meertaligheid en Taalverwerving) since 2016 and also teaches courses on Spanish linguistics in the Bachelor’s program on Spanish Language and Culture at Utrecht University. 

Since 2010 she has been a guest lecturer in the Master’s program for Education at the University of Curaçao, teaching courses and supervising students’ research in the domain of multilingualism, language contact and language acquisition.

summary:
About me in a nutshell: I love to learn and teach about cognitive processes in the human brain - especially using EEG. 

With a background in communication and information sciences, clinical- & neurolinguistics and (experimental) neurophysiology, I am specialised in human interaction, language processing and bilingualism, and how to do research within this field of psychology using various techniques. 

Currently I'm a lecturer at Utrecht University where I teach courses in the Master’s programme Applied Cognitive Psychology and in the Bachelor's programme of Psychology. A large part of my job consist of the supervision of students writing their theses (Bachelor/Master), which I thoroughly enjoy due to their creative ideas and problem-solving skills.

I'm always up for collaboration and expanding my knowledge on experimental techniques, so feel free to reach out.

summary:
Diederika Hoddenbagh's passion is to help people find work that suits them.  Work that gives joy and satisfaction. Motivated people who use their strengths and talents are more productive, more creative and find joy in what they do.  Diederika works with individuals or with teams. She has developed different modules for individual coaching and she also offers different kinds of workshops and Team Facilitation sessions for groups of people working together. Teams can learn to improve their communication, learn to understand each other in spite of different cultural or personal backgrounds and become efficient, performing teams.

Diederika has more than 30 years of work experience with Wycliffe and SIL International, both at home and abroad. She works in the Netherlands and in West-Africa as Career Coach, Team Facilitator and leadership coach. She is fluent in Dutch, English and French.
She has B-level accreditation for the Psychometrical instruments she uses (MBTI, Strong, Belbin, Firo-B).
She is also officially certified and licensed to use The SIMA® : System for Identifying Motivated Abilities®   (www.emergo.com, www.simainternational.com)
She received her license for official coaching practice at Full Circle Development in the UK.

Besides her work for Wycliffe and SIL she also has her own Career Guidance business: 
ISCA: International Study and Career Advise
www.volgendestap.org. Click on flags to find the language of your choice (Dutch, English or French).

Diederika is Dutch. She was born in South Africa, she grew up in the United States, studied in the Netherlands and lived and worked in various European and West African countries. She is married with Hans and they have two grown-up daughters. She now divides her time between working in the Netherlands and traveling to French speaking West Africa doing coaching, Career Guidance or Team Facilitation wherever she goes.

skills: ['Programming', 'Data Visualization', 'Scikit-Learn', 'Education', 'EFL', 'Research ', 'Data Science', 'Literature', 'Project Management', 'Deep Learning', 'Statistics', 'Machine Learning', 'Microsoft Office', 'Pandas (Software)', 'Python ', 'Jupyter Notebooks', 'Presentation Skills', 'Customer Service', 'Team Management', 'Public Speaking']
summary:
I am currently towards the end of my Research Master in Computational Linguistics / Natural Language Processing at the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam. After my Bachelor’s studies in English Linguistics and Literature, my passion for language and my need to contribute to society's modern demands have turned me towards Language Technology. After all, I strongly believe that (personal) reinvention is the natural outcome of the world's continuous change. My current studies have armoured me with a broad perspective and interdisciplinary skill-set, while the research aspect made be adopt an inquisitive approach to everything, asking questions and working very thoroughly towards the answers. In the course of two years, I have worked with various NLP and Text Mining tasks, such as Sentiment Analysis, Named Entity Recognition, Topic Modelling and Classification, Semantic Role Labelling, Argumentation and Opinion Mining, Coreference Resolution and Conversational Agents. I also took a number of extracurricular course in Knowledge Organization and Data Mining Techniques, where I acquired knowledge in structured databases and worked on a hotel recommender system. Through these tasks I also gained a strong Machine Learning and Deep Learning knowledge. I mostly work in the Python programming Language, but I also have basic experience in R and Java. Finally, during my studies I worked in multiple Teaching Assistant positions that deepened my skills and confidence in them. 


This challenging transition from Linguistics to NLP gave me a strong learning drive and mindset and made me a strong proponent of bridging Humanities with STEM subjects. Every day of my studies is a confirmation of how significant linguistic insight is into making automatic systems more robust, efficient, generalizable and interpretable. At the same time, I also found myself leaning towards the engineering aspect, which is what I intend to pursue careerwise and combine with my linguistic background for a well-rounded and efficient execution.

name: Iris van der Zwaag
skills: ['Linguistics', 'Proofreading', 'Editing', 'Research', 'Structured', 'Creative Writing', 'Writing', 'Social Media', 'Translation', 'Photography', 'Microsoft Word', 'Microsoft Excel', 'Microsoft Powerpoint', 'WordPress', 'Interviews', 'Teaching', 'English', 'Dutch', 'Sociolinguistics', 'Language Variation']
summary:
After secondary school, I went to Leiden University to study English Language&Culture. Three years later, BA in hand, I specialised by doing a master's in English Language&Linguistics. I'm mostly interested in sociolinguistics with a hint of phonology: How are words pronounced, what do people think of that, does the region they live in influence their pronunciation? But basically everything that has to do with language and linguistics sparks my interest.

Since I didn't want to go into education, I had to find different ways to use my talents. I had already tutored many individual pupils in English and I am still occassionally doing this. I've been transcribing old manuscripts for Transcribe Bentham and also for Shakespeare's World. I am proofreading and editing for a student company (AthenaSummary & AthenaCheck) and have done some translation work as well. 

I worked at a homework institute for two years and I loved helping the pupils with their homework through explanation and rehearsing. At the start of 2016, I begun with two internships at Calvijn College: research and editorial. Through both internships I've specialised in directions that I'd love to work in, gaining the experience for future jobs.

Even though I didn't want to go into education, I'm still working close to that branche. Who knows what will happen in the future? For now, I'm focusing on editorial work, but I'd be happy to have any job that concerns language and/or linguistics.

Want to know more about me? Just ask!
